description: From Middle French affiance, from affier (from Medieval Latin affīdāre, from *fīdāre, from Latin fīdere) + -ance.

examples: Such feelings promptly yielded to his habitual affiance in the divine love.

entries.meaning: (archaic) A solemn engagement, especially a pledge of marriage.

verbs.description: affiance (third-person singular simple present affiances, present participle affiancing, simple past and past participle affianced)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To be betrothed to; to promise to marry.
